newsitem.title: USA: Merrill says India economic fundamentals are solid.
newsitem.headline: Merrill says India economic fundamentals are solid.

text.p: India's economic fundamentals remain positive despite a host of short-term weaknesses, according to Merrill Lynch analyst William Belchere.

India's industrial growth rate will slip to 8.0 percent in the current fiscal year, ending March 1997, from about 12 percent in 1995/96, said Belchere, who heads Merrill's currency and fixed income analysis and forecasting for Asia.

But thanks to the good monsoon, a bumper harvest may mitigate the impact of falling industrial output, with the resulting gross domestic product growth close to the government's forecast of 6.6. percent for 1996/1997, he said.

In October 1996, Standard & Poor's revised its outlook on India foreign currency rating, currently at BB-plus, to "positive" from "stable," citing an improved economic performance, progress on reforms and stronger external accounts. "The possibility of S&P upgrading India's sovereign rating to investment grade has increased," Belchere said.

While calling India's economic fundamentals "compelling," Belchere warned that export growth in the current fiscal year may end below target, and inflation may rise, leading to higher interest rates and a weaker currency.
On politics, Belchere said the United Front coalition is experiencing pressure and the possiblity of a reunited Congress Party regaining power is increasing.
